title: Will the UN Security Council or UN General Assembly vote on a resolution concerning outer space before 1 May 2021?
possible_answers: Yes, and China will vote for it
Yes, and China will abstain or be absent from voting
Yes, and China will vote against it
correct_answer: Yes, and China will vote for it
preds:
As per the spot from @Ryan-Beck, and the links from @p00h. What counts as first? we will see, I'm leaning to chronological history (for now); http://webtv.un.org/watch/general-assembly-37th-plenary-meeting/6214774543001/
https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/3893852?ln=en
https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/3893851?ln=en

China voted in favor of draft resolution "prevention of an arms race in outer space" item 101a at the meeting on December 7th, part 1 of A/75/397. I think that satisfies the question. Possible I'm misunderstanding or missing another space question that was voted on first, but as far as I've seen this is the first one. Introducing and voting on the draft starts at 25 minutes in this video: http://webtv.un.org/watch/general-assembly-37th-plenary-meeting/6214774543001/
As others have reported there could be a vote this month.

Looks like prevention of an arms race in space will be voted on December 7th. Links via other comments here. Schedule: https://www.un.org/en/ga/info/meetings/75schedule.shtml
Draft resolution: https://www.undocs.org/en/A/75/397
China appears highly likely to vote in favor of the PAROS, currently set for a vote on 7 Dec.
In light of most recent discussion with @lmstansberry, no change to my prior forecast.

@Imstansberry -Great research. Looks like there is also a vote on the 10th.
-International cooperation in the peaceful uses of outer space: report of the Special Political and Decolonization Committee

First Committee Approves 11 Drafts Covering Control over Conventional Arms, Outer Space Security, as United States Withdraws Text on Transparency
https://www.un.org/press/en/2019/gadis3642.doc.htm

@Econja2018 @thefoxrocks
Thanks for the update.  It looks as though (Prevention of Arms Race in Outer Space (PAROS) is on the agenda ahead of other space resolutions.  Based on historical voting, this should be a high score in the "Yes, and China will vote for it" column.  May be able to close this question out in a couple of weeks!

First committee resolution is on the agenda for general assembly Dec 7.
https://www.un.org/en/ga/info/meetings/75schedule.shtml

I like the logic used by @lmstansberry - excerpted below. It appears that the GA voting on space resolutions has become fairly normalized, with China as a steady 'yes' voter to nearly all space resolutions proclaiming non-armament, peaceful use, etc, and since 2009 with these resolutions coming to a vote in December each year. I'd think about a base rate in terms of p(Ch yes vote) | p(GA/UNSC resolution for vote).  From @lmstansberry : 
If you go to the website, https://digitallibrary.un.org/collection/Voting%20Data?ln=en, and sort by Outer Space and then by year under options tab you can see that China voted yes on "prevention of arms race in outer space (PAROS)" every year since 1981. The past couple of years a vote was recorded for "transparency and confidence-building measures (TCBM) in outer space activities", but it was adopted without a vote in years before. China voted yes on this one as well. As already mentioned there will be more resolutions presented in December that China will vote on as well. Extremely high likelihood that China votes yes on a resolution in the GA before 1 May to satisfy this question.

Considering that the General Assembly will not meet again until September 2021 I do not foresee the General Assembly passing anything prior to 1 May.  Currently there are no outer space topics on the UN Security Council Agenda.  Unless a nation conducts an extraordinary space activity I do not foresee any space related resolution prior to 1 May.  The question revolving around if China will vote for it I think depends if CH or RU are the ones the propose it.  Therefore I put all the possibilities at 10%.  Ultimately the fact that there is nothing on the agenda I do not see an outer space resolution being passed.

Interestingly I was expecting the First committee resolution to appear on the General Assembly agenda but I see it is the fourth committee resolution. 
December10 3pm.  The resolution is we support first committee and copus. Not sure if it will be voted on or adopted without a vote.   Still waiting to see first committee items hit the agenda. Link to GA agenda: https://www.un.org/en/ga/info/meetings/75schedule.shtml
Link to resolution: https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/LTD/N20/282/26/pdf/N2028226.pdf?OpenElement

Proposals concerning space and space exploration are fairly common at the UN, with a resolution on the topic being adopted yearly since 1958. Also, since 2013 these resolutions tend to be passed near the middle-end of December of the previous year, or in other words, at the end of the first quarter of the General Assembly session (runs Sep - Sep). So, I forecast a near certainty that a resolution will be adopted, and will be done so before May 1st. Also space is an area of competition between the US and China. China tends to use the space issue to support their narrative  of "respect for the legitimate interests and values of nations, regardless of their social systems or their levels of development". China uses space as a wedge issue to paint US space superiority as militarized and exclusive. Thus, I think it is very likely China would use the UN, as they have in the past, to support their narrative and vote for a resolution as an alternative to US efforts. The only thing driving this down to 90% is the non-standard year we are having with COVID; the global pandemic may divert some attention away from traditional issues and possibly delay past May a vote.

The following article indicates that there's a growing significant chance of a vote on a joint BRICS proposal. The US will likely be against it (that's historically what usually happens) though there's a chance that the new administration will have a serious look at it, in order to mitigate its image of outlaw in outer space. Based on that hope, Chinese and Russians may feel even more prone to make a proposal. The prospect of a US proposal is still very low.
https://www.spacewar.com/reports/BRICS_says_it_wants_to_prepare_legally_binding_tool_to_prevent_arms_race_in_space_999.html
I am moving closer to the team average but I am still not confident a vote will occur by May.  I think the UN will be too focused on COVID recovery.

Updating info:
First committe approved a resolution " The Committee then approved, by a recorded vote of 169 in favour to 2 against (Israel, United States), with 6 abstentions (Australia, Djibouti, Georgia, Palau, Ukraine, United Kingdom), the draft resolution “Transparency and confidence-building measures in outer space activities "     https://www.un.org/press/en/2020/gadis3658.doc.htm  So it goes to GA.

The UN have been relatively ineffective in their attempts to make any relevant proposal to regulate outer space activity for decades. The COPUOS still hosts discussions and managed to get some treaties signed in the past but the opposite views that motivate the US on one side and China and Russia on the other side make very unlikely the possibility of a sudden new proposal before May 2021. The new US administration won't have time between January and May to open fruitful discussions with the other nations. In addition, the US is in the process of building its own alliance and its own set of rules, to be followed unilaterally within its group of partners (Artemis accords and current NASA efforts to gather support)—perhaps hoping to create customary law. There has been no significant change or disaster recently that could push all nations to acknowledge the outer space risks and threats and agree together on norms or code of conduct (at least). Even, if such an event would happen (like the Iridium-Cosmos collision), it is almost impossible to make a deal in such a short time window. This subject is a legal issue which may have tremendous consequences (hinder some states in pursuing their desired strategies), if the wording of a resolution was not adequate. There is however still a small probability that China would attempt a diplomatic move (as they have already tried in the past) to make a proposal. In such a case, there are 99% chances the US would veto it, either by principle (absence of trust in China and belief that they have a hidden evil goal) or for good reason.

Based on the procedural vote ruling, I adjusted my forecast to be closer to my original outside position.  The big question for me, in this case, is how likely is the UN General Assembly to vote on this specifically.  I don't know that this is very likely given all other world issues the US faces with COVID relief, immigration/refugee situations, etc.  I think China's likelihood of taking time on this issue is high, and I believe they are an influential voice on this matter.  Given this, I expect the two most likely scenarios are "No" or "Yes, and China will vote for it."  Hopefully, this is helpful.

@CatherineN Updating after our last conversation.   Pulling back the below comments for everyone's awareness. 
If you go to the website, https://digitallibrary.un.org/collection/Voting%20Data?ln=en, and sort by Outer Space and then by year under options tab you can see that China voted yes on "prevention of arms race in outer space (PAROS)" every year since 1981.  The past couple of years a vote was recorded for "transparency and confidence-building measures (TCBM) in outer space activities", but it was adopted without a vote in years before.  China voted yes on this one as well.  As already mentioned there will be more resolutions presented in December that China will vote on as well.  Extremely high likelihood that China votes yes on a resolution in the GA before 1 May to satisfy this question.
- No change, historically these votes happen in December and the order of resolutions will dictate if China is a yes or if the resolution is adopted without a vote.

No -10% as global pandemic is not disrupting U.N. business so far. Yes, China against +5% if peaceful uses of outer space resolution voted on before no first placement, sustainable development, or confidence building measures. http://undocs.org/en/A/75/251

After a discussion with teammate @lmstansberry, I am reverting back to pretty much what my forecast was, prior to my immediately previous posting.  I accept his reasoning that the best way to understand the question as posed is that: any vote by China in favor of any of the 3 or 4 resolutions that will go to a vote in the GA this week would count as a 'yes and China will vote for it' answer.  Since China has consistently voted 'yes' on several of the resolutions up for a vote, it seems like a very safe bet.  Even if China does vote "no" on the responsible uses of outer space resolution, it wouldn't matter for the purposes of the question.
adjusted based upon consistent voting during Covid and the fact that space issues are routinely voted on during the month of December.
updated my forecast based on team discussion.  China is active in Space topics and generally supportive.

Space is formally on the UNGA first committee agenda (https://www.un.org/en/ga/first/75/pdf/A-C.1-75-CRP.4.pdf). It seems likely at least one resolution will pass out of committee and make it to a UNGA vote.

@jtrusz, @sskells, @pdmonquee and teammates--
A big update on my forecast, based on lengthy conversations with people at NASA and the State Dept who follow these issues closely.  New and refined info:
Outside view stuff:
1) Despite COVID, voting will occur.  So no need to worry that our forecast will get messed up as a result of a vote not occurring.
2)  There has never been a Security Council vote on any space issue, so the only place a vote would come up regarding space will be in the General Assembly
Inside view stuff:
3) There are several resolutions on space that are due to come up for a vote the week of Oct 26 (next week!).  So there will definitely be a resolution that gets voted on prior to May 1, 2021.
4) Of these upcoming resolutions, based on past precedent, China will definitely vote yes on all -- *with the only exception being* that it's not clear how China would vote on the UK's resolution on responsible behavior in space.  So that's the big question.  There is some possibility that China will align itself with Russia on that vote -- that is, vote against.   My contact is going to send me material on China's voting behavior on a cybersecurity issue in the past, in which China aligned itself with Russia in voting against the Western position on a resolution; the "explanation of vote" on that one may help give insight into whether China might also align itself with Russia in voting "no" on the upcoming peaceful uses of space resolution
5) In the meantime, my inside contact's best guess is that China will either vote "against" or will abstain on the UK's responsible behavior in space resolution.
So that's what I have for you at the current time!
I'll switch paradigms for a while and see how that goes.

The agenda for 2020 lists several items concerning space. Assuming they tackle subjects in order, the first is "space as a driver of sustainable development". Next is "prevention of an arms race in outer space" with the first subtopic having the same name and the second subtopic titled "no first placement of weapons in outer space". The last of these appears to be a resolution that gets voted on every year with China voting for. The big question then is whether the preceding topics would have a vote and whether China would vote against. Previous discussion indicates they'll judge this question by the first resolution voted on. I'd guess the first two topics either don't involve votes or China would vote in favor. Another possibility that could lead to China voting against is if the security council addressed a space issue first and China voted against or abstained. I'd guess that has a low likelihood. Overall seems very likely they vote on a space resolution and very likely China votes in favor. Leaving some uncertainty for misinterpretation or information I'm probably missing, the unknowns of the first two agenda items mentioned, weird coronavirus quirks for this session, and the off chance a security council resolution happens first. Agenda: https://www.un.org/en/ga/75/agenda/ "No first placement..." resolution voted on every year: https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/3839972
Updating based on helpful research by @CatherineN
- Awaiting on 2020 schedule update. No change to projection at this time. China is a recurring supporter of Space resolutions.

See below from the 2020 briefing book.  I see no reason why they wouldn't continue to vote on the generic resolutions as they have the past few decades.  If they do vote, China will likely vote yes as it has over the past 20 years. The disagreement between countries is in the specifics. However, leaving 10% chance out there that COVID derails voting until after May of next year.   Widespread support for relevant UN General Assembly First Committee resolutions including on the Prevention of an Arms Race in Outer Space (PAROS), Transparency and Confidence-building Measures in Outer Space Activities (TCBM), and International Cooperation in the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space indicates strong concern for the need to maintain outer space as a peaceful, global commons. But the international community is deeply divided on how to preserve and enhance this security, particularly the threat of an arms race in outer space.
Based on the clarification on what constitutes a vote, as well as the good research by Catherine, Jared, and Mike, I see no reason to modify my forecast at this time.

Based on the great discussion and hard work of the team, I'm updating my forecast.  Seems like China would vote for it to push the idea that they follow the rule of law, but may or may not abide by it.
Reaching out to a friend who works at the UN to determine how much voting is going on that is NOT COVID related.  Pending that answer, adjusted data based on Mike's consistent findings.

@Imanstanberry, great job sleuthing out that voting record website in the UN!  I reacted to your posting in our team chat, with confirmation from the UN librarian that that is the go-to website for country voting records.  
To answer your question, I don't see why the UN wouldn't have a resolution up for a vote in December, and why China wouldn't vote for it, as they have every year since 1983, as you note.    Even with Covid, the UN would still be able to vote on stuff remotely, right? to sum up: I see no need to change my forecast after all.
Updated based on info from our team

-55 on no. Thanks to a comment by @r00k. Initially I was looking at the UNOOSA link which showed few actual votes, but that doesn't appear to be a comprehensive overview of resolutions concerning space. Their comment pointed out that a resolution called "No first placement of weapons in outer space" has been voted on every year. The link below contains the 2019 resolution and voting record. China voted in favor of it. https://digitallibrary.un.org/record/3839972?ln=en So I'm switching to favoring yes with China voting for it. However, I'm not confident mostly because of how this question might be judged. For one, in the case of multiple resolutions concerning space the wording on the question becomes less clear. I would assume that if multiple space-related resolutions are passed and China votes yes on any of them that this question would be satisfied. But the question wording seems built around the possibility of a single resolution passing. Also leaving some uncertainty in case I'm misinterpreting the UN resolution process. I think some clarification about what happens if multiple space related resolutions are passed could be useful for this question.

Based on @CatherineN comment i am changing my forecast for yes to 100%.  I never considered that voting to place a resolution on the agenda for 2021 GA would cojnt as a yes to this question.  But, youknow, looking at the forecast question I think it would. It is a reolution to discuss at next GA issues concerning outer space.

Following the helpful comment provided by @Econja2018, I'm going to revise my forecast, flipping it to the opposite of my original forecast.   Following the link to agenda item 101 of the 74th session (2019) of the General Assembly recommended by Econja2018, here's my understanding of the situation (this now represents an extreme Inside View, vice my original Outside View): Every year for the past 39 years, there's been an agenda item on "Prevention of an arms race in outer space."   And it looks like every year the General Assembly votes to repeat the same issue on the following year's General Assembly agenda.  So for example in December 2019 the General Assembly voted to place "Prevention of an arms race in outer space" on the 2020 GA agenda.   So even though this is not a resolution on something substantive or some geopolitical action to take, it still counts for the purposes of this forecasting question- it is a "UN General Assembly vote on a resolution concerning outer space."  And if these votes typically occur sometime around December, then this year's vote would happen well before May 1, 2021.  According to the 2019 resolution text, apparently China has consistently expressed an interest in matters regarding prevention of placement of weapons in outer space and preventing threat or use of force in space, so I would imagine that China would vote in the 2020 GA in favor of keeping having prevention of an arms race in space on the 2021 GA agenda. Agenda item 101 contains other resolutions having to do with space, but I'll stop there for now and perhaps analyze them later to see if any of them would change my current forecast.

Based on a very preliminary reading. IT seems likely that if a resolution were to come up for vote it would most likely be the China Russia draft proposal.
https://undocs.org/A/AC.105/1224 (Refer pg 7/46 point 28)
Also there is a Space2030 agenda which was supposed to be considered in the 73rd session of The GA but a revised draft of the same has come up earlier this year(https://www.unoosa.org/res/oosadoc/data/documents/2020/aac_105c_12020crp/aac_105c_12020crp_16_0_html/AC105_2020_CRP16E.pdf)
Not sure whether this will be considered in Sept 2021(Which is when the annual sessions for GA happen  or before that.)
Overall believe that if a resolution does come up for vote it could be the China Russia draft or nothing comes up for vote at all. (PS - Feel i am all at sea on this question)

Likely the world will be too busy continuing to focus its efforts and attitudes toward coronavirus.  In the event a motion in passed, it likely will be a moderate issue that is unlikely to cause waves -
No trace of preparation, GA passed, only arms race res are voted, if voted then likely to be against china's recent deployments (hence vote against).

Looking back through some of the linked resources it looks like the last space related vote was 2007, and the US was the sole vote against while China voted for it. Hard to find much info on why but for now I'm going with a low chance of a vote, and if there is a vote I'll assume China is voting in favor. I'm assuming adopted without a vote or by consensus does not satisfy "vote on a resolution" per the question, that seems like the only reasonable reading.

- Since 2010 there have been 20 space related resolutions. (+)
- Since 2010 there has been at least 1 space-related resolution per year. (Base rate = 100%)
- The General Council session for 2020 ends this week. (-)
- COVID has required virtual meetings which I assume slows progress. (-)
- The 2019 General Council session approved 11 draft space resolutions under implementation action (+)
- Most space resolutions since 2010 have been approved by the General Council not Security Council with a consensus vote...meaning no "no" votes. *I consider this a yes vote for China, please clarify which changes the criteria of the question. (+)

Now that my knee jerking has subsided, I read several rationales and the most compelling is from @Econja2018  which points to the actual GA Agenda. After reviewing the lengthy agenda there are two places where space is mentioned one in resources and the other is militarization. See for yourself at https://www.un.org/en/ga/75/agenda/
Now the hard part is what to make of it and will anything get discussed and then put to a vote. Both China and the USA are working hard to get back to the moon soon. Other countries also want a presence so as to not be left out. I give it a 50-50 chance of happening this session and perhaps that is too generous.

With the Presidential Campain in November and the results most likely being contested, I don't see the US pushing for any significant resolutions in the near future. Given China's views differ from the US, I expect China will prefer to work with a new administration vs being more at odds with the Trump administration.

The outside view tells us that there have been 7 space resolutions in the last 20 years with increasing occurrence.  Crowd forecasting calls for 95% no with a 3% yes and a China approval.  On the inside, the latest UN session was postponed in June and cancelled in Sept moving to a yet to be voted on session virtually.  The combination of the US Artemis Accords (bilateral) and a recent proposal by the UK at the UN for Responsible Behavior in Space leads me to believe that a resolution will occur before 1 May and that China will vote against it given their aggressive 5 phase Strategy for Space as part of the China Dream.
Passing a toothless resolution is still a passed resolution.

China, Russia and others sponsored space-related resolutions during the 74th UNGA in 2019. The United States and Israel were the only countries to vote against these resolutions. However, some notable countries like the UK did abstain. It seems very possible Russia and China will re-introduce the measures again at the 75th UNGA to put the US and its close allies on the spot and on record once again as opposing "Transparency and Confidence Building Measures in Out Space Activities." https://undocs.org/en/A/C.1/74/L.60 The COVID-19 pandemic has required virtual diplomacy at this year's UNGA. It is unclear how this reality will affect the UNGA committee's ability to manage its workload. It's possible this year's UNGA will be less productive than recent years, lowering the likelihood of votes on space resolutions.

UN website links related to this topic suggest the action plan is delayed due to COVID, with two major sessions cancelled during 2020 and one postponed without a new date. teleconferences were used for interim sessions. There are two sessions scheduled between now and may 2021 to discuss details of the draft completed in June 2020, which has only recently been translated into other languages. This topic has been under discussion and review since mid 2018. The matter was tabled until 2021. With COVID still a factor in UN operations, the chance of further postponement is relevant. There are no other sessions scheduled for this action after November 2020. The only thing i can find which may be impacted by further delay is China's planned moon landing in 2024, but this is likely an exploratory event and not exploitative - which is the thrust behind China's lunar exploration. If we calculate current frequency of sessions at 6 months, there are chances for one, perhaps two sessions in which this action would come up for vote. I might adjust percentages if I had a clearer understanding of how UN resolutions move through the institution.

I as read the question, I understand it to mean that a resolution on outer space must only come up for a vote (not pass) in either the GA or UNSC by 1 May (7 months away).   Honestly, I'm a bit stumped on this one.  Based on the UN Office for Outer Space Affairs' website (https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/documents-and-resolutions/search.jspx?&view=resolutions), there has been at least one outer space related resolution since before 2000.  However, the majority of those are listed as "adopted without a vote." However as @TDHesslink points out below (thanks for the resource!) there have been several space-related resolution votes per year recently and China normally votes in favor. I guess the biggest wildcard is whether COVID will have such an impact as to preclude normal order and voting before 1 May.  My hunch is that they will want to show that the pandemic will not stymie the UN and will find ways to bring resolutions up for a vote even if in fewer numbers than normal.

Outside view - while UNGA is meeting now, the UNSC could take up the issue over the next seven months.  
Inside view:  UN last adopted a space-related resolution in 2017.  However, Russia has been keen to introduce space resolutions, including a “No first placement of weapons in outer space," which would qualify as a security issue (most recently in 2019).
China has voted with Russia in the past.

Roughly 41 UN resolutions so far in 2020 mostly focused on regional/state issues.  Based on how different the US and China view international law governing space it seems unlikely especially in light of the ongoing economic trade war between the two nations.  On the other hand, this would be an opportunity for China to lead and increase its standing on the world stage.

- There are no resolutions on the UN Office for Outer Space Affairs calendar for the time frame
- China voted for the last two resolutions submitted by Russia
- China try’s to use the UN to impede others nations and follows its own agenda
Don't see this being at the top of state's agenda's this year and not with such politicl turmoil.

I thought @JBURD was right on the money by starting with the Outside view, so following his example and building on it:
Outside view (or Scoping?):  The UN General Assembly only meets once a year, and it is wrapping up its annual September meeting now, so (barring a country calling for an emergency special session between now and May 1, 2020, which as JBURD notes is very unlikely, there is basically nil chance that the General Assembly would vote on a space resolution before next May.
Continuing Outside View:  The Security Council is the only UN body in continuous session (a rep of each of its 15 member states are on call at all times).  So in theory it could meet at any point between now and May 1, 2020, on a space resolution.  JBURD makes a good point that the Security Council only considers issues having to do with peace and security, though, so there would have to be a peace and security element at stake for that body to vote on a space resolution.
Inside View:  Is there a controversy or question regarding space and peace and security that the UN is currently preoccupied with, that could be a catalyst for a resolution?
The UN Office for Outer Space Affairs has not put forth a resolution since 2017: http://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/spacelaw/resolutions.html
The First Committee did approve four draft resolutions intended to avert militarization of outer space in Nov 2019, though: https://www.un.org/press/en/2019/gadis3642.doc.htm If those are draft resolutions, presumably they could be brought up at some point for actual approval?  Since they have to do with security in space, then maybe they would be resolutions that the Security Council might approve?  I haven't so far found any info that indicates that the Security Council needs to or plans to take up consideration of one of the 4 resolutions mentioned in the  link above, so for now I will agree with JBURD's forecast. If a resolution of some sort did come up for a vote, I think China would vote on it rather than abstain; apparently China has its eye on space as part of its Belt and Road Initiative, (see https://www.un.org/press/en/2019/gaspd705.doc.htm )  so I think China would consider itself as having a stake in anything space-related in the UN.  Hard to tell whether China would vote for or against without knowing what the content of a proposed resolution is, though.

While space exploration as definitely entered a new age, and commercialization (in the US) has definitely increased international interest.  COVID-19 has limited UN focus.   The last space treaty was passed in 1984, and the last principle in 1996.  NASA's Artemis Accords are principles to the OST.  There have been five principles passed since 1963 (less than 1% chance).  But, there was a flurry of space law and principles right as space exploration kicked off.  Perhaps its just a feeling, but it seems the US has entered a new age of space exploration, with recent launches and the establishment of the space force.  Consequently, I feel there is some possibility for a vote (though limited).

The 75th session of the UN General Assembly First Committee on Disarmament and International Security is scheduled to meet from 5 October–5 November 2020. Looks like they are working around COVID restrictions at this time.  The following link has outer space discussion in the briefing book.  https://reachingcriticalwill.org/images/documents/Disarmament-fora/1com/1com20/briefingbook/FCBB-2020-outerspace.pdf.  Appears that there is high level of international interest to keep Outer Space discussions and normalization moving forward. Like @TDHesslink stated below, there has been a resolution regarding Outer Space, voted favorable by a unanimous margin, for the past several years, four alone in 2019.  The GA only needs 50% to pass a non-legally binding resolution.   The U.S. has pushed back the most in recent years.  Given the current competitive environment, and more China and Russian alignment and consensus, I foresee resolutions presented that are more favorable to the Chinese that they will vote yes on.  The comments on p. 42 of the UN First Committee briefing book need a deeper look and may impact the probability for this year. Regarding the UN Security Council,  the growing militarization of space, to include the U.S. Space Force, and Russia's anti-satellite tests demonstrate the potential for great powers to be at odds regarding Outer Space for the foreseeable future, so the Security Council is out for now.

UN is slow as molasses. The one in 2017 only happened because it was a the 50th anniversary of something
https://www.unoosa.org/oosa/en/ourwork/spacelaw/resolutions.html

I should never of jumped in this pool!  Thanks to @cdob63 and @r00k for their comment.  So i went to tbe UN website  and learned a bit of commitees an GA workings.  The first committee is working a draft. The worki g draft is the china-russia draft.  There is a godd chance it comes ojt of committee.
So it has to pass the committee and then go to the GA.  The GA does its substantial work thru december (according towikipedia) and the jan-may is more consultations tha  voting.  Not that something couldn't happen then.  But if it did vote, it will be a china approved draft.
So the NO represents the probability it does not clear committee.

https://reachingcriticalwill.org/disarmament-fora/unga
UN General Assembly has favorably voted on 3-4 space-based resolutions every year since approximately 2014. China has consistently voted yes. That said, a security council resolution is much more intriguing, Russia and China both remain concerned by United States activities and policies regarding space and continue to escalate proposals following submission of a draft No First Placement of Weapons in Outer Space Treaty in 2014. Putin opening remarks at 75th UN General Assembly announced intent to submit proposal legal framework for space activities.
https://tass.com/science/1203779
https://www.aninews.in/news/world/asia/china-accuses-us-of-obstructing-talks-aimed-at-banning-militarisation-of-outer-space20200923191348/ There have been no security council resolutions regarding space in the last 10 yrs. However, with India's 2019 ASAT test and United States May 2020 release of Artemis Accords which China appears to consider an attempt by US to set space-based norms outside UN governance - https://thediplomat.com/2020/09/what-does-china-think-about-nasas-artemis-accords/ - China remains concerned with US posture and policy regarding space.

May 2021 is pretty near for such a vote given the paralysis caused by Covid-19. I have no doubt that the pressure to formalize resource extraction on non-terrestrial bodies will be a thing. Lunar and asteroid mining the first that come to mind.

Need to do more research; yet I recall reading an article that Russia has deployed satellites with missiles etc.  Therefore, it must be a resolution that each nation wants to bring up sooner or later, as a space arms race will surely proceed at pace without intervention.

Outside view:  The UN General Assembly meets only once a year.  A nation may request or call a special session.  In the last 5 years, there have only been two special sessions of the UN General Assembly;  The 31st session regarding COVID 19 and a session in 2016 regarding drug issues. Outside view:  The National Security Council meets more frequently but the purpose of the NSC is to address threats to international peace.  So I ask myself (inside view) how likely is there to be a Space situation that impacts international peace?  I am not aware of an existing space incident that would qualify as impacting international peace so I consider this to be very unlikely.
China, Russia and the USA, view space as a open option, why would the UN need to address this issue at this time? Considering the multiple on ground issues facing them at this time.

I am absolutely ignorant on how the UN works. I mean I have no idea if just because someone floats resolution then somehow it magically move from committee to a vote by the general assembly. Recognizing that I am absolutely ignorant on this topic will not prevent me from making a forecast.

There are lots of anodyne things a GA resolution can say that the PRC could either agree to; or rather than abstain, they might take a long lunch during the vote.  However, they are unlikely to abstain on a Security Council resolution.   Still, there are reasons for presenting a Security Council resolution that they'd veto.   I'll probably stick close to these numbers until somebody starts muttering about an actual proposal.  I'm pretty sure this will happen, but it's early days, and I am wrong a lot.
